section.title: Solutions Analytic at Two Singularities: Heun Functions

para.sentence: For an infinite set of discrete values q_{m} , m=0,1,2,\dots , of the accessory parameter q , the function \mathit{H\!\ell}\left(a,q;\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta;z\right ) is analytic at z=1 , and hence also throughout the disk |z|<a.
To emphasize this property this set of functions is denoted by (0,1)\mathit{Hf}_{m}\left(a,q_{m};\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta;z\right), if m=0,1,2,\dots.

The eigenvalues q_{m} satisfy the continued-fraction equation q=\cfrac{a\gamma P_{1}}{Q_{1}+q-\cfrac{R_{1}P_{2}}{Q_{2}+q-\cfrac{R_{2}P_{3}}{ Q_{3}+q-\cdots}}}, in which P_{j},Q_{j},R_{j} are as in §31.3(i).

More generally, (s_{1},s_{2})\mathit{Hf}_{m}\left(a,q_{m};\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta;z\right), if m=0,1,2,\dots, with (s_{1},s_{2})\in\{0,1,a,\infty\} , denotes a set of solutions of (31.2.1), each of which is analytic at s_{1} and s_{2}.
The set q_{m} depends on the choice of s_{1} and s_{2}.
The solutions (31.4.3) are called the Heun functions.
